We‚Äôve seen the devastation the climate crisis has had on our country: homes and neighborhoods in ashes, some of the most active hurricane seasons on record and historic flooding in the Midwest.

Starting on January 20th, we'll tackle this crisis head-on here and around the world.

What the headline doesn't tell you: this disproportionately affects Black and Latina women who often lack paid sick leave or the ability to work from home.

Expanding economic opportunity has never been more important.

Nearly 3M students nationwide don‚Äôt have access to the internet at home‚Äîleaving many school districts this year scrambling to find ways to reach students. Pandemic or not,  and I are committed to expanding broadband access to every American.

On Human Rights Day,  and I are committed to supporting and defending human rights at home and around the globe, building a world where everyone has the opportunity to thrive no matter their race, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, disability, or gender identity.

No matter where you live, everyone wants to be able to get a job and keep a job.

No matter who you love, everyone wants to be able to buy a home and keep a home.

 and I understand that and together we‚Äôll create an America where opportunity is within reach for everyone.

Joe and I were raised to respect the dignity of work. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve always fought for working people‚Äîfrom standing up for families who lost their homes to joining picket lines to advance workers‚Äô rights. Our administration will continue to put working people front and center.

It is our sacred obligation to care for our nation‚Äôs veterans and do right by them and their families.  and I are committed to ensuring they get the care they need when they return home. 

On Veterans Day and every day, thank you to all who have defended our nation.

Howard will always be home.

As a proud graduate of Howard University, I‚Äôm always excited to hear from HBCU students. We are family‚Äîno matter which school we call home, or where we pledged.

This is not the time for political games. People are losing their loved ones and their homes, and they need resources to recover. Now.

Protecting vulnerable nursing home residents has been a top priority for the Trump Administration. We've provided nursing homes with resources and training to improve infection control, and we're rapidly providing incentives to those facilities making progress fighting COVID-19.

Today we announced $333 million in first round performance payments to over 10,000 nursing homes. These nursing homes are being recognized for demonstrating significant reductions in COVID-19 related infections and deaths between August and September.

Our unprecedented public-private partnership with  and  will provide convenient and free vaccination to residents of nursing homes across America, another historic achievement in our efforts to get a safe and effective vaccine to Americans as fast as possible.

Today we awarded nearly $360M to programs supporting maternal and children's health. These funds support communities to provide voluntary, evidence-based home visiting services to pregnant women and parents with young children up to kindergarten entry.

.‚Äôs ETC model will reward providers for keeping patients healthier and at home by encouraging home dialysis, and provide incentives to increase the rate of transplants to help those with kidney failure avoid dialysis altogether.

Since before the pandemic, CMS has been strengthening oversight of facilities that fail to meet minimum registered nurse coverage requirements- improving registered nurse staffing, resulting in a decrease in nursing homes w/o registered nurse.
In March,  issued temporary regulatory waivers to ensure that nursing homes have the staff necessary to care for patients, ; that those staff are able to focus on patients care:
To ensure nursing homes are adequately staffed during the  pandemic,  took action to maximize workforce flexibilities ; infection control for the duration of the public health emergency (PHE).

Additionally,  never decreased fines for nursing homes who failed to meet compliance requirements before the  public health emergency. In fact, in the 2 years prior to the pandemic, the average per day CMP had an increase of ;$2000 per fine.

. strengthened the nursing home survey process to ensure it was data driven ; that we had consistency across the nation, ; has seen the number of nursing homes w/ enforcement actions ‚¨ÜÔ∏è by 15% ; the total number of Civil Monetary Penalty‚Äôs collected ‚¨ÜÔ∏è by 22%.

Since early March,  ; its network of ~5,000 state-based inspectors have conducted thousands of surveys, ; continuously worked w/ the states to survey as many nursing homes as possible, regardless of their previous history.

It's worth noting that, while Kirkland Life Care performed well in some areas, the nursing home's inspection rating on Nursing Home Compare is only 3/5 stars.

These early inspections accelerated our understanding of  and how it spreads and affects patients, which informed our later guidance and actions such as expanding telehealth coverage in nursing homes.
The outbreak in Kirkland represents a clear failure of a massive nursing home corporation to care for individual residents.

: Life Care facilities have, on average, higher fines than other American nursing homes. In 2019, Life Care facilities across the country were fined a total of $1.69 million for poor-quality care for residents.

Life Care of Kirkland is not a small, mom ; pop run business, as it sounded coming from a corporate VP on 60 Minutes. In fact, it's part of a $3.2 billion network of hundreds of nursing homes across the country.
. cannot physically be in every nursing home every day - it is the facility's job to provide the care to residents in a safe way that is sustainable over the long term.

.'s responsibility as a regulator is to hold nursing homes accountable for keeping nursing home residents safe. Life Care failed to report the outbreak timely ; keep its residents safe, ; we refuse to apologize for holding Life Care accountable for its failures.
. will not stand aside when nursing home residents are in danger.  We take immediate action to protect them.
Our Kirkland inspection was absolutely critical in helping us understand how the virus affected nursing homes, ; it informed our next steps as we considered how to inspect other facilities.

When nursing home residents‚Äô lives are at stake, it is our duty to act. We couldn‚Äôt simply ignore the Life Care crisis or watch from afar. Too many lives were at stake ‚Äì and not just in Kirkland. We knew this had broader implications.
Now, to Kirkland:  reminded nursing homes of their responsibility to provide effective infection prevention ; provided free training, prior to the first outbreak in the U.S.
To be clear: nursing homes bear the primary responsibility to keep residents safe.

Yesterday, we issued an EUA for the first OTC, at-home, rapid diagnostic test for . The Ellume COVID-19 Home Test is authorized for people age 2+ with or without symptoms. It can be used completely at home without a prescription.

We issued a new EUA for BinaxNOW COVID-19 Ag Card Home Test for at-home use with a prescription. The test is authorized for use in patients age 4+ who are suspected of COVID-19 by their healthcare provider ; are within the first 7 days of symptom onset.

The BinaxNOW COVID-19 Ag Card Home Test will be offered in partnership with a telehealth service that will take users step-by-step through the sample collection process ; help reading ; understanding the results.

The home test uses self-collected nasal swab samples for people age 15 and older and adult-collected nasal swab samples for people age 4 and older who are suspected of  by their health care provider within the first seven days of symptom onset.

Today, we issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for an antigen test for  that allows people to perform the test at home with a prescription. There are now three tests authorized by the FDA that can be used completely at home.

Today, the FDA issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for the first over-the-counter (OTC) fully at-home diagnostic test for . The Ellume COVID-19 Home Test is authorized for people 2 years old and up, including those not showing symptoms.

FDA issued an EUA to LabCorp for its Pixel COVID-19 Test Home Collection Kit for use with LabCorp‚Äôs COVID-19 RT-PCR Test for non-prescription use. The Pixel COVID-19 Test Home Collection Kit is the first COVID-19 direct-to-consumer test system.

If results are positive or invalid, a health care provider will call the user. Negative results will be delivered by email or online portal. While many home collection kits can be prescribed with a simple online questionnaire, this direct-to-consumer kit removes that step.

Today, we authorized the first  test system consumers can buy online or in a store without a prescription. The test is for people ages 18 ; older ; it allows them to collect their own nasal sample at home ; send it to a lab for processing.

We authorized the first diagnostic test for use with home-collected patient samples to detect both  ; influenza A ; B (flu). Under a health care provider‚Äôs order, patients can collect their own nasal sample ; ship it to a lab for analysis.

With just one swab or sample, combination tests that are authorized for use with home-collected samples can be used to get answers to Americans faster, in the comfort and relative safety of their home, which allows patients to continue to quarantine while awaiting results.

The test is for prescription use, with a sample self-collection kit, by people suspected of respiratory viral infection consistent with .  Under a health care provider‚Äôs order, patients can collect a sample at home and ship it to the lab for analysis.
Today, the FDA authorized the first diagnostic test for use with home-collected samples to detect both  ; influenza A ; B (flu).

Dr. A-Scott: Social gatherings continue to be a problem area for transmission. From 9/22-28, we identified 719 new cases. 49 reported attending social gatherings. People who went to social gatherings had an average of 6.5 contacts. The number for the average positive case is 5.
